bibl.title: Letter from Charles E. Magoon to J.W. Amesse, June 30, 1908

div1.p: Magoon urges Amesse to support an end to the quarantine of Cuba, arguing that there is no danger to the United States.

div1.head: Letter from Charles E. Magoon to J.W. Amesse, June 30, 1908
div1.opener:
Havana, June 30, 1908.
Dr. J. W. Amesse,
Havana.
Dear Doctor:
div1.p:
Major Kean has showed me your letter with reference to the
advisability of the removal of the quarantine against Cuba, in
which you state the time has not yet come, in your opinion, for
this step. This opinion seems to be based upon the assumption
that yellow fever may exist in the interior of the island and con-
stitute a menace to the health of the southern states of the union.
In my opinion, however, the sanitary supervision exercised by the
National Sanitary Department over all the municipalities of the
island is suffifiently thorough to negative this assumption. In
this connection I would call your attention to the fact that medi-
cal officers of the army or of the navy are on duty with United
States troops at almost all the important cities of the island,
and these officers are always invited by the local sanitary officers
to see suspicious cases occurring in these towns. No case suspicious
of yellow fever has been reported in several months by these medi-
cal officers. The only place where the existence of a yellow fever
focus can be suspected is Santiago where three cases have developed
in the past three months, the last on June 4th. As the infected
zone in Santiago has been under a rigorous system of supervision,
the appearance of so small a number of cases shows that the in-
fection is under control and in process of extinction, and so far
2- Dr. J.W.A.
it should not be regarded as a source of danger to points as far
distant from Santiago as the southern ports of the United States.

In order that you may satisfy yourself by a personal in-
spection that yellow fever is not being concealed or in some mys-
terious way escaping recognition in the interior towns of Cuba,
I invite you to pay a visit of inspection in company with a repre-
sentative of the National Sanitary Department to such parts of
the republic as you may wish to see. The expenses of this trip
will, of course, be paid by the state.
div1.closer:
Very respectfully, Magoon
Provisional Governor. Dr. J. W. Amesse,
Past Asst. Surgeon P.H. & M.H.Service,
Havana.
Invitation not accepted
